section.title: Cloning a Physical Disk

para.quote: Everything in the UNIX system is a file.

section.para: I never fully grasped the everything's a file concept until I tried (expecting to fail) to use the qemu-img convert sub-command to create a virtual disk image of an actual hard drive. This is possible in part due to the philosophy laid down by Dennis Ritchie and Ken Thompson when they first created UNIX: everything's treated as a file. The synopsis of the convert sub-command is below.
In this section we'll look at a standard 1GB USB thumb drive and then clone it into a disk image. Using parted, here's what that disk looks like to the host system:

To convert the thumb drive we're first going to unmount the drive, then use the qemu-img command to perform the actual conversion. While unmounting the drive I use the -l option which means to unmount lazily, i.e., to wait until there is no activity going on before attempting to unmount.
